case_name: Arjan Singh alias Puran v. Inder Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1950 filed in Supreme Court against judgment and decree dated 28th February 1946 of High Court of Lahore in Regular Second Appeal No. 887 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Appeal  Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1950  against a judgment and decree dated 28th February, 1946, of the High Court of Judicature at Lahore in Regular Second Appeal No. 887 of/942.

facts.text: Plaintiff Arjan Singh alias Puran brought suit in court of Subordinate Judge Jullundur against Inder Singh, Kartar Singh and five others.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff, Arjan Singh alias Puran, brought a suit in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Jullundur, against Inder Singh, Kartar Singh and five oth- ers,

facts.text: Suit for declaration that will executed by Inder Singh in favour of Kartar Singh about 14 years ago was null and void as against plaintiff, first defendant's reversionary heir.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration that a will executed by the first defendant, Inder Singh, in favour of the second defendant, Kartar Singh, about 14 years ago was null and void as against the plaintiff, who was the first defendants rever- sionary heir after his death.

facts.text: Properties in suit: half share of 395 kanals land in Kadduwal, half share of 837 kanals 11 marlas in Pattar Kalan, four houses in Pattar Kalan.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint companyprised a half share of land measuring 395 kanals in the village of Kadduw- al, another half share of land measuring 837 kanals and 11 marlas in the village of Pattar Kalan, and four houses in the latter village.

facts.text: Pedigree: Sehja Singh 4th ancestor of plaintiff, sons Jodha Singh and Jai Singh, Inder Singh grandson of Jodha Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In the pedigree attached to the plaint showing the relationship of the parties, the plaintiff claims Sehja Singh as his 4th ancestor. Jodha Singh and Jai Singh are shown as Sehja Singhs sons. Defendant No. 1, Inder Singh, is Jodha Singhs grandson.

facts.text: Parties are Jat agriculturists governed by customary law in alienation of ancestral property and succession.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that the parties are Jar agriculturists governed by the customary law in matters of alienation of ancestral property and succession,

facts.text: Under customary law, sonless proprietor not competent to make will of ancestral property if collaterals up to 5th degree.

anchor.surface_text: and that as a sonless proprietor under this law is number companypetent to make a will in respect of his ancestral property, when there are companylaterals up to the 5th degree,

facts.text: Entire property in plaint was ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: and as the entire property mentioned in the plaint was ancestral, the will made by the first defendant in favour of the second defendant

facts.text: Second defendant Kartar Singh claimed adoption by first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: in favour of the second defendant who claimed to have been adopted by the first defendant was invalid and ineffectual.

facts.text: Plaintiff born on 22nd July 1919, minor when will made, suit within time.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiff was born on 22nd July, 1919, and was a minor when the will was made, and so the suit was within time.

facts.text: Suit contested mainly by second defendant Kartar Singh who pleaded properties not ancestral as regards plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested mainly by the second defendant, Kartar Singh, who set up his adoption, and pleaded that the properties were number at all ancestral as regards the plain- tiff.

facts.text: Defendants 3 to 7 remained ex parte.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 3 to 7 remained ex parte.

facts.text: At trial, admitted that land in Kadduwal not proved ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, it was admitted that the land situated in Kadduwal was number proved to be ancestral.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held land in Pattar Kalan not shown ancestral; Sehja Singh had three sons: Jodha, Jai, Pohlo.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that even the land in Pattar Kalan was number shown to be ancestral by the evidence adduced on the side of plaintiff, as it was found that the companymon ancestor, Sehja Singh, had number only two sons called Jodha Singh and Jai Singh, but a third son named Pohlo,

facts.text: No presumption of ancestral property from equal shares of two sons when third son existed.

anchor.surface_text: and that from the mere fact that the two sons enjoyed the land in equal shares, numberpresumption companyld arise that the property was ancestral and descended by inheritance from the companymon ancestor, when numberhing was known about the share of the third son.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge found adoption invalid and suit within limitation but plaintiff no locus standi to contest adoption.

anchor.surface_text: He recorded findings in favour of the plaintiff on the issues as to adoption and limitation, but he also held that the plaintiff had numberlocus standi to companytest the validity of the adoption as the period of limitation had expired long before he was born.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Plaintiff appealed to District Judge, filed application under Order XLI r27 CPC for additional evidence: kami beshi statement Pattar Kalan showing Pohlo gave up interest.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff preferred an appeal to the companyrt of the District Judge. He filed an application under Order XLI, rule27, and section 151, Civil Procedure Code, for leave to adduce additional evidence. The document he wanted to be taken on record and companysidered, and of which it was alleged that he was number aware at the trial, was a kami beshi statement relating to Mauza Pattar Kalam, which companytained a numbere that the third son, Pohlo, gave up his interest in the ancestral property in favour of his brothers.

facts.text: District Judge allowed additional evidence application on 17th March 1942 before hearing appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th March 1942, that is, even before he heard the appeal, the District Judge allowed the applica- tion.

facts.text: District Judge appeal heard on 24th April 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was heard on 24th April, 1942.

facts.text: Additional evidence: naqsha kami beshi 1849-50 and muntakhib asami-war 1852 stating Pohlo relinquished share.

anchor.surface_text: Referring to the two entries found in the naqsha kami beshi prepared in 1849-50 and the muntakhib asami-war pre- pared in 1852, which stated that Pohlo had relinquished his ancestral share,

facts.text: District Judge reversed Subordinate Judge, decreed plaintiff's suit; held entries genuine, land Pattar Kalan ancestral qua plaintiff, adoption not true, suit within time, custom no will away property.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge reversed the decision of the Subordi- nate Judge and decreed the plaintiffs suit on the strength of this additional evidence. He held that the entries relied on for the appellant were genuine and number forged and that as Pohlo had relinquished his share, the land in Manza Pattar Kalan was ancestral qua the plaintiff. He further found that the suit was number barred and was within time under article 120 of the Indian Limitation Act, but that the adoption set up by the second defendant was number true. As the custom of the district did number permit a proprietor to will away any portion of his property, whether ancestral or self-acquired,

facts.text: District Judge decreed including Kadduwal lands conceded not ancestral and 4 bighas 16 biswas Pattar Kalan with third parties.

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff had, in the opinion of the District Judge, a right to companytest the will. On the basis of these findings, he decreed the plaintiffs suit in its entirety, including the lands in the village of Kadduwal which were companyceded to be numberancestral and also an area of 4 bighas and 16 biswas of land in Pattar Kalan which, accord- ing to the record of rights, was number in the possession of Jodha Singh and Jai Singh, but with third parties.

facts.text: Kartar Singh second appeal to High Court Lahore.

anchor.surface_text: Kartar Singh, the second defendant, took the matter on second appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held no proof Pattar Kalan ancestral, additional evidence not justified, entries interpolated.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court held that there was numberhing to show that the land in Pattar Kalan was ancestral and that the District Judge was number justified in admitting additional evidence in the shape of the nabsha kami beshi and the muntakhib asami-war records. They further pointed out that even a superficial observation of the original documents led one irresisti- bly to the companyclusion that the entry regarding Pohlo giving up his share was a subsequent interpolation.

facts.text: High Court: entire Pattar Kalan not ancestral, suit dismissible under s7 Act II 1920 as non-ancestral immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: They came to the companyclusion, therefore, that the entire land situated in Pattar Kalan was also number-ancestral and that the suit should have been dismissed in toto, inasmuch as under section 7 of Act II of 1920, numberperson is empowered to companytest any alienation of number-ancestral immoveable property on the ground that such alienation is companytrary to custom.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds District Judge not justified in admitting additional evidence under Order XLI r27.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, the learned Judges of the High Court were right in holding that the District Judge was number justified in admitting this evidence under Order XLI, rule 27.

facts.text: Entries in settlement registers spurious, subsequent interpolation.

anchor.surface_text: Even a superficial observation of the original docu- ments leads one irresistibly to the companyclusion that this entry was a subsequent interpolation. In naqsha kami beshi there was alrerady a remark in that companyumn and the remark relied upon which has very awkwardly been inserted there is with a different pen and in a different ink.

facts.text: No proof common ancestor Sehja Singh owned Pattar Kalan properties; entered in names of two sons equal shares, nothing about third son Pohlo; pedigree shows fourth son Hamira.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing to show that the companymon ancestor Sehja Singh was possessed of the Mauza Pattar Kalan properties which are found subsequently entered in the name of two sons in equal shares, with numberhing said about the share of the third son Pholo. As a matter of fact, the pedigree table shows that there was a fourth son called Hamira.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 2, 1951 by CHANDRASEKHARA AIYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. March 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by CHANDRASEKHARA AIYAR J.

issues.text: Whether it was open to the High Court to interfere with the discretion exercised by the District Judge in allowing additional evidence to be adduced

anchor.surface_text: It was strenuously argued by the learned counsel for the appellant that it was not open to the High Court to inter- fere with the discretion exercised by the District Judge in allowing additional evidence to be adduced and that even assuming that there was an erroneous finding of fact, it must stand final as a second appeal can be entertained only

issues.text: Whether the discretion to receive and admit additional evidence under Order XLI, rule 27 CPC was properly exercised by the District Judge

anchor.surface_text: The discretion to receive and admit additional evidence is not an arbitrary one, but is a judi- cial one circumscribed by the limitations specified in Order XLI, rule 27, of the Civil Procedure Code. If the additional evidence was allowed to be adduced contrary to the princi- ples governing the reception of such evidence, it would be a case of improper exercise of discretion.

issues.text: Whether on examining the evidence as it stands, some inherent lacuna or defect becomes apparent justifying application of Order XLI rule 27

anchor.surface_text: the legitimate occasion for the application of the present rule is when on examining the evidence as ii stands, some inherent lacuna or defect be- comes apparent, not where a discovery is made, outside the court, of fresh evidence

issues.text: Whether the appellate court is able to pronounce judgment on the materials before it without taking into consideration the additional evidence

anchor.surface_text: The true test, there fore, is whether the appellate court is able to pronounce judgment on the materials before it without taking into consideration the additional evidence sought to be adduced.

arguments.claim: Discretion to admit additional evidence is judicial not arbitrary, circumscribed by O41 r27 CPC; if contrary to principles, improper exercise, ignore evidence

anchor.surface_text: The discretion to receive and admit additional evidence is not an arbitrary one, but is a judi- cial one circumscribed by the limitations specified in Order XLI, rule 27, of the Civil Procedure Code. If the additional evidence was allowed to be adduced contrary to the princi- ples governing the reception of such evidence, it would be a case of improper exercise of discretion.

arguments.claim: No proof common ancestor Sehja Singh owned Pattar Kalan properties; entered in two sons' names equally, nothing about third son Pholo; pedigree shows fourth son Hamira; no presumption of ancestral

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing to show that the common ancestor Sehja Singh was possessed of the Mauza Pattar Kalan properties which are found subsequently entered in the name of two sons in equal shares, with nothing said about the share of the third son Pholo. As a matter of fact, the pedigree table shows that there was a fourth son called Hamira.

holdings.text: The discretion to receive and admit additional evidence under Order XLI, rule 27, CPC is a judicial one circumscribed by the limitations in the rule and is not arbitrary; improper exercise of discretion allows higher courts to interfere and ignore such evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The discretion to receive and admit additional evidence is not an arbitrary one, but is a judi- cial one circumscribed by the limitations specified in Order XLI, rule 27, of the Civil Procedure

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion must follow principles governing reception of additional evidence; contrary admission is improper and non-existent for decision-making.

holdings.text: The legitimate occasion to apply Order XLI, rule 27, CPC is when examination of existing evidence reveals an inherent lacuna or defect, not for fresh evidence discovered outside court.

anchor.surface_text: the legitimate occasion for the application of the present rule is when on examining the evidence as ii stands, some inherent lacuna or defect be- comes apparent, not where a discovery is made,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Privy Council precedents in Kessowji Issur v. G.I.P. Railway and Parsotim v. Lal Mohan emphasizing inherent defects over external discoveries.

holdings.text: The true test for admitting additional evidence under Order XLI, rule 27, CPC is whether the appellate court can pronounce judgment on the materials already before it without the additional evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The true test, there fore, is whether the appellate court is able to pronounce judgment on the materials before it without taking into consideration the additional evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from Privy Council authorities to determine necessity based on sufficiency of existing record.

holdings.text: The District Judge was not justified in admitting the additional evidence under Order XLI, rule 27, CPC as there was no inherent lacuna in the evidence, admission was made before examining the record or hearing the appeal, and the court could pronounce judgment without it.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, the learned Judges of the High Court were right in holding that the District Judge was not justified in admitting this evidence under Order XLI, rule 27.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No gap in trial evidence requiring filling; premature order on 17 March 1942 before hearing on 24 April 1942; appellate court able to decide on existing materials.

holdings.text: The entries in the naqsha kami beshi and muntakhib asami-war records regarding Pohlo relinquishing his share are spurious and subsequent interpolations.

anchor.surface_text: Even a superficial observation of the original docu- ments leads one irresistibly to the conclusion that this entry was a subsequent interpolation. In naqsha kami beshi there was alrerady a remark in that column

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court observations on different pen/ink, awkward insertion, illegibility, absence in corresponding copies, and illogical placement fully agreed with by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: There is no proof that the common ancestor Sehja Singh owned the Pattar Kalan properties, which were entered in equal shares of two sons with nothing about the third son Pohlo or fourth son Hamira; no presumption of ancestral nature arises.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing to show that the common ancestor Sehja Singh was possessed of the Mauza Pattar Kalan properties which are found subsequently entered in the name of two sons in equal shares,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial evidence insufficient even without additional evidence; equal shares of two sons insufficient for presumption given unknown shares of other sons; pedigree confirms additional sons.

holdings.text: A finding of fact based on improperly admitted additional evidence and ignoring intrinsic defects in such evidence is not conclusive in second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that a finding of fact, however erroneous, cannot be challenged in a second appeal, but a finding reached on the basis of additional evidence which ought not to have

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 100 CPC limits second appeals, but improper procedural evidence admission allows interference to ensure just decision.

anchor.surface_text: As laid down by the Privy Council in the well-known case of Kessowji Issur v.G. I. P. precedents.cited_proposition: the legitimate occasion for the application of Order XLI rule 27 is when on examining the evidence as it stands, some inherent lacuna or defect becomes apparent, not where a discovery is made outside the court of fresh evidence and the application is made to import it

precedents.citation: Parsotim v. Lal Mohan 2 58 I. A. 254

anchor.surface_text: and they reiterated this view in stronger terms even in the later case of Parsotim v. Lal Mohan  2 . A. 254 judgment on the materials before it without taking into companysideration the additional evidence sought to be adduced.

precedents.cited_proposition: reiterated in stronger terms the view on the legitimate occasion for application of Order XLI rule 27 regarding additional evidence

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, the learned Judges of the High Court were right in holding that the District Judge was number justified in admitting this evidence under Order XLI, rule 27. Even companyceding that the reception of additional evidence was proper, the District Judge has failed to companysider the inherent infirmities of the entries in the settlement regis- ters relied on. for the appellant and the several criticisms that companyld justly be levelled against them for showing that they were spurious. He took the entries to be genuine.
